Authors:
Ruben Damian Elias-Roman, Ned B. Klopfenstein, John W.
Hanna, Mee-Sook Kim
Title:
Armillaria mexicana (Agaricales, Physalacriaceae), a newly
described species from Mexico
Keywords: pathogenic fungi, new species, orchard trees
Abstract:
Armillaria mexicana is described as a newly recognized
species, based on morphology, DNA-sequence data, and phylogenetic
analyses. This species is clearly different from previously reported
Armillaria species in North, Central, and South America. It is
characterized by the absence of fibulae in the basidioma; abundant
cheilocystidia; hyaline, apparently smooth at the light microscope
level, but surface appears slightly to moderately rugulose at the
scanning electron microscope level; it is differentiated from other
previously described Armillaria species by morphological characters,
including annulus structure, pileus and stipe coloration, and other
structures. DNA-sequence data [Internal transcribed spacers 1 and 2 with
5.8S, Large subunit (LSU) D-domain, 3’ end of LSU-Intergenic spacer 1,
and translation elongation factor 1α (tef1α)] show that A. mexicana
sequences are quite distinct from sequences of analogous Armillaria
species available in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis based on tef1α
sequences place A. mexicana in a well-separated, monophyletic clade that
appears basal to the polyphyletic Armillaria mellea complex.
